# Solving the problem of abundance: venture capital and the making of asset-driven inequalities  

Nils Peters  

To cite this article: Nils Peters (04 Nov 2024): Solving the problem of abundance: venture capital and the making of asset-driven inequalities, Review of International Political Economy, DOI: 10.1080/09692290.2024.2422062  

To link to this article: https://doi.0rg/10.1080/09692290.2024.2422062  

# Solving the problem of abundance: venture capital and the making of asset-driven inequalities  

Nils Peters  

Department of Sociology, London School of Economics and Political Science, London, UK  

# ABSTRACT  

The 2010s were an era of abundant capital for investors but limited opportunities to put it to profitable use. This paper traces the origins of dealing with the 'problem' of having to convert large accumulations of cash into appreciating assets. It puts venture capitalists in the US at the center of this history. Charting venture capital's 1950s emergence, 1960s formalization, and 1970s institutionalization, I show how early venture capital investors built a financial infrastructure that safeguarded the appreciation of their assets. Venture capitalists' influence increased as institutional investors (as funders) and startup employees (as investees) became enrolled in this infrastructure and oriented their actions toward its imperatives. I argue that in their handling of abundance, venture capitalists constructed and deepened asset-driven inequalities. Empirically, the paper makes a contribution by demonstrating that vast accumulations of (personal) wealth played a decisive role in this process and highlights the importance of stark inequality well before the neoliberal turn or quantitative easing. Conceptually, I show that venture capitalists' solution to a personal problem became useful at a much larger scale. The paper argues that we should read this influence as conditioned on elite surplus and access to a financial infrastructure.  

# KEYWORDS  

Venture capital; financialization; infrastructure; asset economy; limited partnership; abundance  

## Introduction  

Since 2008, scholars have tried to make sense of what is causing both ultra-low interest rates and worldwide stagnation, with many citing an abundance of capital. For some, this is excessive savings in industrialized countries, and China specifically, whose ‘savings glut (Bernanke, 2015) is driving ‘secular stagnation’ (Summers, 2016). More recently, others have highlighted the emergence of a ‘saving glut of the rich (Mian et al., 2020): a substantial growth in savings among the top $1\%$ of the income and wealth distribution in the US. This concentrated accumulation of capital means that it becomes increasingly difficult to find profitable outlets for investment. This was further aggravated by over a decade of expansive monetary policy, during which major central banks like the Fed injected vast amounts of liquidity into the financial system (Schwartz, 2016a). This policy coupled quantitative easing with ultra-low interest rates, ensuring cheap credit and driving down yields on bonds. In their search for yield, investors increasingly funneled capital toward riskier forms of equity investment.  

Venture capitalists (VCs), investors pursuing high-risk investments in technology startups, have borne the brunt of this tidal wave of capital. In the US, venture capital investment increased 7-fold between 2008 and its peak in 2021 to a volume ofUS $\$254$ billion (OECD, 2022). Montalban et al. (2019) argue that the global growth of inequalities [...] creates surplus savings on a global scale and a significant part of these are attracted to Silicon Valley's eco-system based on the proximity of venture capital and the new economy’ (p. 809). Venture capitalists, in turn, react to this abundance of funding' (Kenney & Zysman, 2019, p. 40) by investing money into ‘unprofitable and unproven tech companies’ (Srnicek, 2016, p. 30). This matters because despite their small footprint relative to the overall financial sector, venture capitalists wield considerable influence over our financialized economy (Epstein, 2005; Krippner, 2012). In 2020, seven out of the 10 largest companies by market capitalization were VC-funded (Cooiman, 2023) and VC has been centrally important in creating the tech-driven growth paradigm made famous by Silicon Valley and espoused in OECD countries around the world (Rothstein, 2022). This paper aims to make sense of VCs as agents of abundance in a financialized environment.  

Venture capitalists’ historical role in enabling the handling of abundance, and deepening inequalities, has so far received little attention. This paper argues that VCs pioneered solutions to absorb and invest large accumulations of cash. When this became a ready-made solution in the 2010s, VCs drove the financialization of the startup by funding and sustaining new (and often unprofitable) business models, changed industries by exercising discretion over where abundant funds were to be deployed, extended the reach of institutional investors as these form the funding base for most venture capital investment, and used the inflow of capital for personal enrichment. This way, VCs deepened asset-driven inequalities.  

Empirically, the paper demonstrates that vast accumulations of (personal) wealth played a decisive role in this process and should be read as an important pre-history to typical focal points of the financialization literature. Beginning in the 1950s, there is a consistent theme of elites and wealthy individuals looking to deploy excess cash. Channeling abundance preceded the deregulation of financial markets in the 1970s and 1980s and the financialization of the firm in the 1980s and 1990s. Even though VC funds form and functioning perfectly catered to the post-2008 macroeconomic environment, they had been up and running decades prior. This highlights the importance of stark inequality well before the neoliberal turn or quantitative easing.  

The central problem that VCs needed to solve was how to convert large quantities of capital into quickly appreciating equity investments or assets. The paper here builds on recent scholarship that has highlighted the importance of assets for capitalist dynamics (Adkins et al., 2020; Braun, 2016, 2020; Christophers, 2023). Adkins et al. (2020) claim that after decades of asset appreciation and stagnant wages, asset ownership—rather than income from waged labor—now primarily stratifies society. The authors have stressed that the asset economy is driven by the middle class through house ownership and prices. Against this, I make the case to focus on the $1\%$ to examine how inequality is constructed from the top. This paper shows that asset dynamics as structuring forces of society are initiated, perpetuated, and amplified by VC investing. Protagonists of VC's rise actively engineered their exposure to asset dynamics and appreciation.  

However, innovations that VCs pioneered toward this aim needed decades to take hold and unleash their full effect. Conceptually, the central insight here is that VCs solution for a personal problem of abundance unintendedly served as a map for the large-scale handling of the more recent macro problem of abundance. I show that early VC investors incrementally built a financial infrastructure through legal and organizational innovations that catered toward their personal enrichment and that of their allies. VCs increasingly exercised considerable influence as their funders (institutional investors like pension funds, insurances, and endowments) and investees (startups) started to engage with this infrastructure and oriented their actions toward its imperatives—what I term the emergence of an alliance of asset owners. The paper argues that we should read this influence much more explicitly as conditioned on elite surplus and access to this financial infrastructure.  

This paper synthesizes conceptual and historical scholarship to demonstrate the centrality of abundance for VC's role in the making of financialization. I draw on two data sources: secondary literature on the genesis of venture capitalism in the US, and primary interview data with early venture capital investors from the Bancroft Library Oral History Archive. Not having been involved in the interview process, I tread carefully with the interview data and only present it in conjunction with other sources for contextualization. I employ a radical historicist method (Knafo, 2017) to analyze this data and build a narrative attuned to agents' innovations, separate intentions from outcomes in social struggles, and tease out what difference VCs made for the broader process of financialization.  

For this historicist reconceptualization, I review the literature on venture capital's role in deepening inequalities through innovation and financialization. I find that framing VC investing as speculative excess risks underestimates the political stakes of the changes VCs affected, highlighting the need to acknowledge venture capitalists’ agency in the co-production of structures. I use the concept of financial infrastructure to undermine structuralist analysis and account for the scaling of VCs' localized solutions to macro importance. In the main empirical section, I offer a different reading of existing histories of VC through the lens of abundance and asset appreciation. I trace VC's rise by focusing on its 1950s emergence, 1960s formalization, and 1970s institutionalization of venture capital. In the following discussion, I reflect on developments since the 1980s to tease out how wealth inequality and privilege were a key factor in the emergence of VC and how it ties in with scholarship on asset ownership and appreciation as a new stratifying force in society.  

## Venture capital and inequality in financialized times  

Scholars in political economy, economic sociology, and management studies have linked VC and inequality across multiple domains. These literatures intersect in the process of financialization, where VCs have been researched as speculative financiers, drivers of innovation and macro-level inequality, and of the financialization of the firm.  

The literature highlighting VC's speculative quality situates VC investing in the macro context of a financialized world that offers fewer and fewer opportunities for profitable investments in the ‘real economy. Typically following Brenner's (2006) Long Downturn, the argument goes that declining rates of profitability in the manufacturing sector led to a reallocation of capital into speculative financial investments to make profits, driving finance's expansion. This expansion of finance has been criticized as undermining sound economic growth by diverting capital away from productive, and toward speculative, uses’ (summarized by Beck & Knafo, 2019; see also Langley, 2021, p. 383). Srnicek (2016; see also Valliere & Peterson, 2004) argues along these lines when he observes that the boom in the 1990s ^was an era driven by financial speculation, which was in turn fostered by large amounts of venture capital (VC) and expressed in high levels of stock valuation. As US manufacturing began to stall after the reversal of the Plaza Accord, the telecommunications sector became the favored outlet of financial capital in the late $1990s^{\prime}$ (P. 20). Beyond the Dotcom boom, scholars have more recently focused on the Big Tech boom during the 2010s. Kenney and Zysman (2019) observe that the vast increase in VC money used to fund startups has led to a situation where these companies can operate at a loss for extended amounts of time. This misallocation of capital, they argue, leads to disruption without generating profit' and is destroying economic value′ (Kenney & Zysman, 2019, p. 39; also see Elder-Vass, 2021). VC is part of the broader trend of financialization and hence contributes to the deepening inequalities through the inflation of the financial sector at the expense of the 'real economy.  

A separate strand of research recognizes the importance of VCs in fostering innovation in growth-centered political economies (Schumpeter, 2005; Schwartz, 2016b), yet remains attuned to their role in the reproduction of broader inequalities (Lazonick & Mazzucato, 2013). Most prominently, the National System of Innovation approach analyzes the importance of an eclectic range of actors in innovation processes (Freeman, 1995). Kenney (2011) argues that VC managed to stabilize its position within the US National System of Innovation through strong performance and financial returns as a proof of concept, setting off a dynamic where strength begot strength. The National Venture Capital Association, VCs' lobbying body, promoted these successes in Washington, DC, further strengthening VC's position. Deepening Kenney's account, Rothstein (2022) provides a detailed explanation of how the formation, rise, and endurance of social blocs enabled VC's rise and their disproportionate influence. Using the concept of the ‘tech-VC bloc, he argues that venture capitalists credibly sold an innovation-led growth model to legislators. VC here becomes an endogenous factor in the now wider-spread innovation-focused policy paradigms, tying themselves to the success of these political proposals.  

The tech-VC bloc advocated for a model that materialized as the new economy business model (Lazonick, 2013) in the 1990s. This model became prevalent in the US high-tech sector and comprises high growth, inter-firm labor mobility and lends itself to the imperatives of the shareholder value revolution in increasingly financialized capitalism. However, despite its wide-spread embrace in policy circles, there is reason to doubt that innovation-led growth is a tide that lifts all boats equally. Lazonick and Mazzucato (2013) argue that there has been an increasing separation between those economic actors who take the risks of investing in innovation and those who reap the rewards from innovation’ (Lazonick & Mazzucato, 2013, p. 1094)—a shift in the risk-reward nexus. The authors outline how VC is often mistaken as a glowing example of risk taking, where in fact other actors in the National System of Innovation were a necessary condition for their startup investments and reaping benefits of pre-existing research—VCs come in late in the innovation process.  

Like Lazonick and Mazzucato,Schwartz (2016b,2019） is concerned with innovation and inequality in financialized capitalism. However, he develops his analysis by focusing on inequality at the firm level. Schwartz investigates the relationship between an overall, macro slowdown in economic growth (secular stagnation) and rising inequality due to firm-level changes in strategy and structure. Firms’ strategies increasingly depend on intellectual property rights (IPRs) to ‘éxtract monopoly rents from other firms and consumers’ (Schwartz, 2016b, p. 228), exacerbating inter-firm inequality. Firms structures have changed with the pressure to maximize shareholder value, shifting labor and physical assets outside the legal boundaries of the firm, producing individual-level inequality and weakening the rate of growth of consumption’ (Schwartz, 2016b, p. 228). Overall, inter-firm inequality suppresses investment and individual-level inequality suppresses demand, yielding a state of secular stagnation. IPRs are central to the operation of firms in the knowledge economy, and the monopoly rents they enable promise huge upsides for investors in the company. VCs operate here as investors in a capitalist contradiction, seeking returns in tech startups while furthering overall stagnation through the financialization of the firm. Cooiman (2024) has analyzed in more detail how VCs imprint their financial imperatives on startups (see also Shestakofsky, 2024).  

In sum, the existing literature has outlined how venture capital has been affected by different aspects of financialization, whether it is the decline of manufacturing and the rise of speculative finance or the congruence with imperatives of the shareholder value revolution and the financialization of the firm, and how this in turn deepened economic inequalities. This paper aims to refocus our understanding of VC and inequality toward elite actors and asset dynamics. To achieve this, we need three interventions in the literature: A stronger emphasis on venture capitalists’ role in co-producing financialization, and within this, an orientation away from the speculative framing of finance toward a conceptualization of how abundance accompanied this process.  

First, political economy accounts of VC underplay the agency of financiers in co-producing structural shifts in the operation of finance. Scholars exogenize VC's business model and investors appear to be spurred by a lack of productive outlets for investment. The institutionalist literature reviewed above is more attuned to the organizational and legal innovations integral to this. However, while all accounts emphasize the importance of various actors and levels of analysis, entrepreneurial clusters, and the state receive the most attention. These contributions are less attuned to specific actors within this emerging type of investing that made a difference in its present-day operation. We lose sight of the wealth inequality that was baked into VC investing from the very beginning.  

Second, accounts centering on speculation misread the political stakes of capital abundance and VC's involvement with it. This critique of finance holds onto the idea of a real economy vs. a speculative one and reduces its potency to a moralizing critique of financiers. Implicitly, our understanding of VC's involvement in inequality comes out of the typical focal points of the financialization literature (like the neoliberal turn in the 1970s) and centers on exuberant market transactions of investors, making this a problem of regulation or even psychology. This forgoes the option to trace problematic developments back even further and identify mechanisms that enabled them to persist.  

Third, and closely related, scholars do mention abundance but do not make it a genuine concern in their analysis. Kenney and Zysman (2019) observe a ‘vast increase of VC money, with Schwartz's backdrop of secular stagnation commonly linked to concentrations of vast amounts of capital (Bernanke, 2015; Mian et al., 2020; Summers, 2016). Within the Long Downturn view, VCs have been analyzed as part of a system clogged with excess capacity and savings (Riley, 2023, para. 3). This is a missed opportunity because analyzing the handling of abundance enables us to plot a line from individual level concentrations of wealth toward their large-scale significance for inequality.  

Against this, I first propose to put asset dynamics at the center of our understanding of inequality. In the Asset Economy literature, scholars have moved away from the productionist toward a post-foundational view of finance, trying to understand phenomena like speculation not as an aberration but as the very stuff of financial life (Adkins et al., 2020, p. 19). This paper focuses on VCs efforts to turn abundant cash into appreciating assets. This is not about one-off speculation but the construction of durable infrastructures for asset appreciation, which enrolled tech workers and institutional investors alike. The political implication is that this could not simply be scaled back, reversed, or reallocated to the ‘real economy (Dutta,2023).  

Second, I claim that the focus on the handling of abundance can reveal important mechanisms for asset-driven inequality that otherwise remain hidden. I contend that VC investing started as investment experiments of a monied elite in the 1950s. To demonstrate the importance of concentrations of capital, I trace how elite actors made innovations and navigated structural conditions to ensure the appreciation of their assets. The focus on the $1\%$ should be insightful for understanding inequality. This does not mean we will lose sight of broader societal effects—what matters here is that a small group of financiers remade the world at large. In the next section, I will outline the conceptual framework for tracing the origins of VC to its present-day influence.  

### The construction of financial infrastructures  

This article traces the VC-led making of the alliance of asset owners, a group of actors in possession of abundant funds who were actively invested in constructing the legal and organizational, and beyond that, the economic and technological environment for the appreciation of their assets. Conceptually, we are looking at the making of a financial infrastructure, a process that is always a co-production of agency and structures, of VCs making their own history but not under circumstances of their own choosing. A key claim of this paper is that small VC-led innovations unintendedly served as a ready-made solution for institutional investors much later on. The concept of financial infrastructures offers us analytical purchase in three ways: First, it helps to work against dichotomies and highlight co-constitution of agency and structures. Second, by emphasizing that this construction is a socio-technical process, we can get a more detailed account of what exactly constitutes structures without having to fall back on generalizing terms. Third, infrastructure helps us account for how small solutions scaled (often in bursts) to affect the macro level economy.  

Keeping with the intention to safeguard against privileging structures in the explanation (Beck & Knafo, 2019; Knafo & Dutta, 2020), I contend that an infrastructural approach lends itself to highlight agency. Importantly, our conception of agency needs to go beyond highlighting actors’ actions in one-off situations like a successful lobbying attempt or a single innovation. Instead, the interaction between agents and the infrastructures they are building must highlight agents’ continuous engagement. Pinzur (2021), while not concerned with VC specifically, gives a fine-grained account of how actors’ contributions create and shape financial infrastructures. He circumvents the usual elaboration of how structural and instrumental power approaches open a gap for infrastructural power by contrasting social structural and infrastructural power. Elites wield social structural power by utilizing their ‘political and economic power to ensure infrastructural advantages, exemplified in the ability of financial firms and lobbyists to mold market infrastructures' (Pinzur, 2021, p. 647). This shaping from without contrasts with Pinzur's understanding of infrastructural power as a way of shaping from within: To examine infrastructural power means to pay attention to what contributions actors make to the operation of infrastructure, and what discretion they exercise over it. This is the conception of agency I will employ in this paper.  

Scholars have further deployed the concept of infrastructure to incorporate different degrees of materiality. On the ‘most material end of the spectrum, infrastructure can be understood as facilitating the movement of physical things. On the conceptual end, infrastructure might be understood as a heuristic device’ (Bernards & Campbell-Verduyn, 2019) that draws together key functions. Scholars draw on infrastructures when trying to explain the socio-technical production of outcomes. This might involve financial analysts and trading terminals or high frequency traders and microwave towers (Beunza et al., 2006; MacKenzie, 2018; Petry, 2021). In the case of the financial infrastructure of the alliance of asset owners, socio-technical analysis allows us to highlight the importance of the law. In the way that Pistor (2013) discusses the extension of legal infrastructure′ (p. 318) that made the global derivatives market possible, this paper specifically examines the legal arrangement of the limited partnership as integral for scaling VC's influence. Soener and Nau (2019) have discussed the importance of the limited partnership as an organizational structure for elite power more generally, while Nicholas (2019, chapter 5) has discussed its importance specifically for VC (also see Kenney, 2011). Its construction engendered new relative dependencies on processes and dynamics of asset appreciation.  

Lastly, the concept of infrastructure has been used to show how the agency of financiers  has  often unintentionally affected  large-scale  change.  Walter and Wansleben (2020), for instance, trace the construction of central bank infrastructural power through processes of formalization. Inherent in tracing the process of formalization is a concern with how innovations, small scale changes became routinized, written into policy or law, and thereby scaled to exert much more influence and structure behavior at a larger scale. They seek to demonstrate that innovations in finance [...] became successfully enlisted as constitutive features in a new macroeconomic governance regime’ (Walter & Wansleben, 2020, p. 626). This is similar to institutions-focused accounts of financialization. Carruthers (2015) sees financialization as a result of the ongoing capitalist drive to preserve the underlying institutionalist preconditions of capitalist markets: property rights, information, regulation, and failure. He makes a crucial point about unintended consequences, stating that ‘[m]any of these changes started as local solutions to specific problems, but unintentionally engendered complexity and path dependency’ (Carruthers, 2015, p. 393). Streeck and Thelen (2005) have called this ‘incremental change with transformative results' (p. 9). While there is an emphasis on incremental change or even a ‘stalactite model of change’ (Djelic & Quack, 2003, p. 309) in some of the institution building accounts, what this paper shows is that some incremental changes led to explosive growth altering entire industries. The infrastructure concept has an edge over institution building approaches because it puts stronger emphasis on the scalability of localized solutions, tracing how something becomes routinized and deployed at scale, often rapidly.  

The notion of financial infrastructure should ultimately serve us to make claims about the power relations at play. My conception of VC infrastructural power is that these actors had considerable discretion over building and bending the limited partnership for personal enrichment. With regard to startup employees and institutional investors, VCs were also able to govern their allies by enrolling them into the routines and interests associated with limited partnership investing, namely fast asset appreciation. However, in the history, this paper is concerned with, the effects of making people dependent on and engaged with the new financial infrastructure become more indeterminate over time. VCs held infrastructural power in the sense that they made substantial contributions to the operation and scaling of the infrastructure, but with scale lost discretion to exercise power over it. The early days of venture capital are the ideal starting point to trace how this story unfolded.  

### 1950s: finding an outlet for excess cash  

Today's VCs pride themselves on their mission to disrupt legacy industries and to challenge the status quo. However, if we go back to the beginnings of modern VC investing, we find that pioneers were the heiresses and heirs of steel, oil, railroad, and real estate empires. The Rockefellers, Carnegies, Phipps, and Whitneys ran family offices for their investment activities and made informal venture investments based on personal connections (Johnson, 2008, p. 22). American Research and Development, an investment company commonly cited as the first VC firm, was managed by George Doriot, a former military general with excellent links to Harvard and the East Coast establishment. Nicholas (2019) highlights that a direct lineage from the early entities based on family wealth to various modern VC firms' (p. 5) can be traced, underlining their defining and enduring influence.  

VC's organizational form developed as this type of investing spread from the East Coast to the West Coast. The first venture capital firm on the West Coast, Draper, Gaither, and Anderson (DGA), was founded in 1959 by two military generals and the former chair of RAND and the Ford Foundation. As Kenney (2011) points out, ‘the first three [partners of DGA] were members of the highest levels of the U.s. business and policy elite' (p. 1698). Elite connections were essential for raising capital for the fund. DGA raised US $\$2.4$ million from two family offices (Rockefeller and Heller), US $\$1.5$ million from the investment firm Lazard Freres, andUs $\$1.2$ million from the Gadran Corporation (Berlin, 2014, p. 160; Nicholas, 2019, p. 156). The overall fund size was US $\$6$ million. As one early VC observed, [hJowever much money [General Anderson] wanted just flowed in from these East Coast people (Lucas, 2009, p. 10). Hence, Berlin (2014) concludes that DGA “must be understood as seeding the modern venture capital industry not by radically departing from prevailing East Coast models of power, capital, and influence, but instead by importing and modifying those models for a West Coast environment that had not yet established its own institutions' (p. 156).  

However, the fact that the West Coast had not yet established its own institutions does not mean that there was no risk of capital investing before DGA's arrival. Since the mid-1950s, a largely informal VC investing community had formed in the San Francisco Bay Area which became known as the Group' (Nicholas, 2019, p. 208). In today's terminology, these people would be considered angel investors'—high-net-worth individuals providing financial backing for very early-stage companies in exchange for equity. These investments happened largely outside formal investment structures or firms. Among ‘the Group' were, most notably, Reid Dennis and Pitch Johnson, who later became presidents of the National Venture Capital Association (NVCA). Johnson further details that this informal group consisted of 12 people who met for monthly dinners (Johnson, 2008, p. 21). In this context, he recounts a particularly insightful anecdote from the early days of venture investing:  

One thing we did that was almost amusing—there were two streets in Palo Alto called Commercial and Industrial. Entrepreneurs were beginning to start companies on their own, and so we used to go down Commercial. We did one time, literally, go down there in our car and walk along, knock on the doors and say, Want any money today? kind of thing. (Johnson,2008,p.23)  

On the one hand, this illustrates the informality, local connections, and low competitiveness with which deals were made at the time. On the other, it highlights that investors were in search of profitable outlets for their capital, in fact, any outlet. VC was a financing model in search of an application. In orthodox accounts, VCs are said to solve a simple problem of the market economy: How to connect people with good business ideas but no money to investors with money in search of ideas (Kaplan & Lerner, 2010). In this view, VC is a textbook example of the capital allocation problem which explains the existence of this type of financial intermediary. Yet historically, capital scarcity is the opposite of what actors were dealing with in the early days of venture capital. We can see a consistent theme of elites and wealthy individuals looking to deploy excess cash.  

### The emerging alliance of asset owners  

While finding an outlet for excess cash is the necessary first step, the second concerns the modalities of securing investment returns. Notably, in the above examples, capital was not distributed as credit (with the expectation to have it repaid with interest) but in exchange for equity. Any hope of multiplying invested money rested on an increase in the value of said equity. The second VC fund on the West Coast, Davis & Rock, showcases how old’ East Coast money was soon met by newly rich startup employees as a driving force for the establishment of VC and an alliance of asset owners. The key link between these two actors is rapid equity (asset) valuation increases through the intense work culture in startups.  

A prime example of this is the engineers of Fairchild Semiconductor. Before joining Fairchild Semiconductor, this group worked at Shockley Semiconductor where they attempted to replace germanium with silicon as the primary material for transistor construction (Miller, 2022). Known as the ‘traitorous eight, they collectively abandoned Shockley to start a new business:  

When the eight engineers left Shockley Semiconductor, one of them, Eugene Kleiner, used his family connections to contact Hayden Stone, the East Coast investment bank. The business proposal was forwarded to Arthur Rock, at the time a Hayden Stone investment banker in New York. Rock and his immediate superior visited the start-up and agreed to raise $\$1.5$ million. [...] Rock then approached Sherman Fairchild, the owner of Fairchild Camera, who agreed to invest $\$1.5$ million with the proviso that Fairchild be allowed to purchase the shares of the eight founders for $\$300,000$ apiece should the venture prove successful. Within three years, Fairchild bought the founders’ shares, and the founders no longer had any equity in the firm. As is well known, almost immediately engineers began to leave Fairchild to launch new firms. (Kenney & Florida, 2000, p.107)  

There are two important elements in this brief history. After leaving Fairchild, these engineers not only launched new firms but also financed Arthur Rock's first limited partnership, Davis & Rock. This exemplifies the increasingly close bonds between financiers and entrepreneurs that came to define Silicon Valley's rise (Kenney & Florida, 2000, p. 108). It also marks the starting point of an alliance between two groups of actors with a keen interest in asset appreciation. As I will show below, this thread will run through the following two decades and prompt various legal and financial innovations.  

Even more importantly, Fairchild is an early example of how remuneration and ownership mattered for the development of the VC industry and Silicon Valley more broadly. Key employees became part owners of the firm, although their shares could be purchased from the Fairchild owner at a previously agreed price. This setup indicates that income from wage labor was set to be outpaced by potential income from asset ownership of shares in fast-growing tech companies. However, the fact that all engineers left right after being forced to sell their shares shows that this arrangement did not cater to the central importance of sustained asset appreciation for employees. If entrepreneurs or managers did not get shares of the company that enabled them to benefit financially from the firm's performance, they simply left. Neither on the investor nor on the entrepreneurial side a functioning ownership structure had developed yet.  

In response to this, legal and financial innovation was borne directly out of the Fairchild case. Lécuyer (2005) argues that former Fairchild Semiconductor engineers started new firms as vectors for personal enrichment and technological innovation' (p. 294). Two of these engineers, Robert Noyce and Gordon Moore, went on to found Intel and worked with a Silicon Valley law firm to devise a stock ownership plan which enabled employees to hold onto their stock (Kenney & Florida, 2000, p. 110). This proved widely influential and became a model for VC-backed startups in the following decades. Kenney (2011) emphasizes the importance of this as stock options aligned employee interests with that of the entrepreneurs and venture capitalists—namely generating capital gains. The prospects of a large pay-off at a liquidity event attracted many of the very best engineers and executives and motivated them to work incredibly long hours' (p. 1691).  

DGA and Davis & Rock presented the first serious steps into the formalization of an up to this point largely informal investment style. Capital pushing into early-stage  companies  showcased  opportunities  for  asset-based  enrichment  and actors embarked on experimentation to formalize mechanisms to secure these gains. This was a trial-and-error process-the transition between informal and formal investing required problem-solving on various fronts.  

### 1960s: organizational experiments  

The two main drivers of the formalization of VC investing were the Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) program and the introduction of the limited partnership as the organizational form for VC. Coincidentally, the first limited partnerships DGA and Davis & Rock, and the SBIC program were both launched in 1958. Analytically, this offers an opportunity to highlight how agency mattered for the eventual large-scale adoption of the limited partnership in venture capital investing. In the late 1950s, the US government made increased efforts to support small businesses. Policy makers at the time sought to close a funding gap for entrepreneurial finance which was estimated to be $\operatorname{USS}500$ million (Nicholas, 2019, p. 134). Cold War antics, particularly the Sputnik crisis of 1957, instilled an urgency to make funding for new technology companies available. This was further amplified by an influential study by the Federal Reserve Board, which put particular emphasis on the importance of making capital available for newly established businesses (Kenney, 201l, p. 1692). This assessment culminated in the launch of the SBIC program in 1958. For the following decade, this program was an indirect way for the US government to fund innovation and technology development. Instead of giving grants or loans directly to companies, the SBIC acted as a financial intermediary which received government loans.1  

To start a SBIC, a private investor acting as prospective SBIC operator had to pay in at least US $\$150,000$ . This paid-in capital could receive a $200\%$ leverage in the form of government loans at favorable interest rates, for a total volume of US $\$450,000$ . The possible leverage decreased gradually for starting capital under US $\$150,000$ . which disincentivized investors to form larger SBICs. Furthermore, legislators sought to protect investee companies from takeovers by capping the amount of equity that could be purchased through an SBIC at $20\%$ . This meant that investors could not take controlling stakes in companies (Kenney, 2011, p. 1693). The literature is not clear on how SBIC operators earned an income while waiting for their investments to deliver returns. It can be assumed that due to their small size, administration costs were relatively low and that investors lived off returns from previous or concurrent investments. This suggests that operating an SBIC was only possible for individuals with substantial savings or wealth. Investors would eventually receive a return on their investment when the investee company was acquired or went public on the stock market.  

Limited partnerships, on the other hand, existed long before VC (Nicholas, 2019, p. 145). The first VCs to make use of them, DGA and Davis & Rock, retained their basic features. VCs act as general partners in the partnership and fundraise from investors who become limited partners with their investment. General partners are expected to contribute their private money to the fund, which originally served to demonstrate that they also have skin in the game. At DGA, for instance, the principals invested US $\$600,000$ of their own savings (Kenney, 2011, p. 1699). Additionally, limited partners are paying a $2{-}3\%$ management fe for their investment in the VC fund. With this money, the VC firm finances its operations and pays investors′ salaries. The most decisive difference compared to earlier organizational forms for VC investing came in the form of remuneration and profit sharing. DGA reset the rules for how profits were shared upon the fund's liquidation. General partners of the fund retained $40\%$ of profits, whereas limited partners received $60\%$ . Davis & Rock operated on a similar framework where profits were shared according to the $80/20$ rule: $80\%$ of profits went to limited partners and general partners received $20\%$ . This distribution eventually became the industry standard (Berlin, 2014, p. 159; Kenney, 2000, p. 102). The pay of general partners was now tied to fund performance.  

### Limited partnerships and the route to formalization  

Both SBICs and the limited partnership largely replaced the informal forms of venture investing. The SBIC program was initially successful, and, as Kenney (2011) observes, due to the rapid success of SBICs investing in electronics, it appeared that the SBIC Program was going to become an important factor in the VC industry’ (p. 1694). However, the limited partnership eventually became the dominant organizational form for VC investing. What explains this outcome?  

First, there were several structural advantages of the limited partnership inherent to its organizational form. SBICs were legally restricted from owning more than $20\%$ of equity in a firm. As a debt-fueled vehicle with government-guaranteed loans, investments were subjected to stringent rules. The $20\%$ limit made it impossible to do follow-up investments in promising firms, an otherwise lucrative tactic to increase potential future payoffs. This is because in a high-risk investment environment in which most companies fail, increasing ownership in the few that are going well can translate into large returns. In a limited partnership, no such requirements limited investment tactics. General partners fundraised for equity investments in their fund, and limited partners did not get involved with the day-to-day investing of the fund. This gave VCs investing out of limited partnerships more room to innovate investment strategies.  

Second, an even greater limiting factor was that a capitalization of US $\$450,000$ maximized leverage. Investments in startups are highly risky, and a certain number of investments in different companies are needed to ensure an adequate probability of success. At this level of capitalization, SBICs were effectively too small to make a sufficient number of investments for risk diversification (Kenney, 2011, p. 1693). By contrast, the limited partnerships DGA and Davis & Rock raised US $\$6$ million andUs $\$5$ million respectively. This allowed them to pursue a portfolio approach to investing where losses can be offset by outsized gains from a small number of investments. Whereas informal investing appeared to be based on oversupply on the investor side, this indicates that the formalization of VC made a baseline quantity of capital necessary for profitable investing.  

Finally, the limited amount of capital that SBICs could effectively absorb (a capped leverage disincentivized investments larger than US $\$150,000$ made them unattractive to institutional investors. As I will show below, the moment institutional investors accepted VC limited partnerships as a viable asset class proved pivotal for the rise of VC. This raises an important point about capital and scale: The viability and sustainability of solutions sometimes depend on their capital intensity. In important ways, SBICs were unable to cater to the next financial order of magnitude.  

Besides these ‘pulling’ structural features of the limited partnership, there undoubtedly was an agential ‘push’ that sought to accelerate the SBIC program's demise. More precisely, it came under attack for limiting venture capital investing ‘proper? Surprisingly though, this charge was not led by VCs but by an institutional investor: the Ford Foundation. Under the leadership of Roger Kennedy, the Ford Foundation funded business associations which represented the interests of venture capitalists and sought to facilitate its expansion. In 1967, Small Business and Venture Capital  Associates published the report  Encouraging Venture  Capital for Small Business. This report characterized the SBIC program as ‘marred by incompetence' and that éexcessive federal regulation was primarily responsible for this (Kenney, 2011, p. 1696). It concluded by recommending the termination of the SBIC program. Kenney argues that despite ongoing federal support for the program, the report drove venture capitalists to abandon the SBIC program (ibid.).  

The problems outlined above meant than some of the most successful SBICs decided to pay off the government and further pursued their investments through limited partnerships. A SBIC Pitch Johnson (a former member of ‘the Group') started with Bill Draper in 1962 was converted into a limited partnership, Sutter Hill (Johnson, 2008, p. 27). While DGA itself performed rather poorly (Berlin, 2014, p. 163), several funds adopted this structure and started to attract more and more funding from limited partners. Among these funds, besides Davis & Rock, were later household names like Kleiner Perkins, Sequoia Capital, and the Mayfield Fund (Draper, 2008; Kenney, 2000, p. 109). As the limited partnership grew in numbers and importance throughout the late 1960s and early 1970s, the structures that were tentatively built by an elite seeking to do venture investing were gradually stabilized and scaled by actors with significantly larger pools of cash to deploy. Nicholas (2019) calls limited partnerships a ‘conduit for wealthy investors’ (p. 147) to make risky investments.  

In sum, we have traced a direct line from the elite beginnings of VC into its formalization, and how this hinged on and further entrenched their privileged position (e.g. sizeable personal investments required as general partners, and the generous participation in profits through the 80/20 rule). We can see how the ability to deal with abundant capital begins to matter for the development of financial infrastructure, as SBICs proved too limiting for VC investing. We can further see how institutional investors are increasingly keen to join the alliance of asset owners, wanting to put more money into limited partnerships. As I show in the following section, this became more and more important as fund sizes started to increase: The pioneering work of the small-scale cash-rich prepared the investment ground for the large-scale cash-rich.  

### 1970s: scaling the financial infrastructure  

Handling abundance meant channeling large accumulations of cash held by single entities (high net worth individuals, family offices, insurances, corporations) into quickly appreciating assets. Alongside the problems associated with formalizing an investment model, like balancing money inflows with limited investment outlets, these actors faced increasing pressure from the macroeconomic and institutional environment of the late 1960s and 1970s. One problem on the national level was that economic growth started to slow and the US government was looking for an adequate policy response. At the same time, price inflation caused asset deflation in the 1970s. As Adkins et al. (2020) explain,‘inflation seriously eroded the wealth of the top decile and centile of households-—those whose wealth was invested in financial assets, such as stocks, bonds, or Treasury bills and whose income derived primarily from interests, dividends, rents, and capital gains. Throughout the 1970s, wealth holders were at a loss to find safe avenues of investment that would protect their assets from depreciation (p. 35).  

This situation likewise affected institutional investors. Due to legal restrictions, institutional investors were mostly invested in bonds (with falling returns) and had difficulties investing in stocks or other equities. The major obstacle that deterred institutional investors from investing in a highly risky asset class like VC was the 1974 Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) which tightened the rules for private pension fund investments. ERISA introduced the so-called “Prudent Man’ rule which required fiduciaries to diversify the investments of pension plans so as ‘to minimize the risk of large losses unless it is clearly prudent not to do so' (Klesch, 1977, p. 27). As a result, pension fund managers adopted more conservative investment strategies out of fear of being held liable.  

VC and institutional investors shared the problem of asset deflation. However, a closer look at the manufacturing sector at the time reveals an interesting development. As Harris (2023) points out, ‘[b]etween 1979 and 1986, total manufacturing as a share of gross national product stayed nearly flat, but the sector's composition changed a lot. Computers and machinery, electronic and electric equipment, instruments, and aircraft increased their percentage share by double digits, while all other manufacturing categories declined’ (p. 406). Given these growth rates, returns from venture investing in high-growth tech startups potentially remained an island of asset appreciation within this deflationary sea. Investment in high-growth tech startups became a viable solution but faced the two obstacles: First, institutional investors needed to overcome legal barriers to invest money into funds that could make this type of investment. Second, early VCs and entrepreneurs were sensitive to rates of capital gains taxation, as these directly impacted their net earnings.  

### ERISA easing and capital gains tax reduction  

The Ford Foundation's involvement noted earlier was the first clear sign that institutional investors were set to join the alliance of actors invested in tech asset appreciation. From the early 1970s, VCs made increased efforts to entice institutional investors to invest in their funds. When Don Valentine raised the US $\$5$ million fund for Capital Management (later Sequoia) in 1972, they made the conscious decision to only take money from tax-exempt sources (Kenney, 2000, p. 113; Valentine, 2009, p. 55). Another outlier in terms of limited partner composition was the fund Reid Dennis raised for Institutional Venture Associates in 1974. Six insurance companies and the Ford Foundation contributed US $\$19$ million, which constituted $45\%$ of all venture capital funding raised that year (Dennis, 2009, p. 31). This foreshadowed how much of a difference capital from institutional investors could make for the financial clout of the VC industry.  

However, this required overcoming contemporary rules and norms limiting the flow of institutional capital into VC. The politics and process of the ERISA clarification have been covered comprehensively, and scholarly accounts have focused on lobbying by the NVCA and lawmakers (Kenney, 201l, p. 1707; Nicholas, 2019, p. 173). Don Valentine credits the president of the Ford Foundation with a considerable impact on the easing of ERISA rules (Valentine, 2009, p. 23). It is difficult to imagine from today's perspective, what has been called the age of asset manager capitalism? (Braun, 2021), that in the 1970s Roger Kennedy had been on a years-long campaign to convince various government actors that investing in equity was prudent for institutional investors. Effectively, these lobbying activities meant that the earlier tendencies among wealthy private investors to invest in (privately held) stocks were now starting to make an impact on the level of government.  

At the same time, levels of capital gains taxation became a highly politicized question. In 1976, Jimmy Carter proposed to get rid of the distinction between the taxation of ordinary income and capital gains. At the top rate, this would have effectively doubled the  capital  gains tax to $70\%$ . In response to this, resistance from various actors that staked their hopes on tech-driven asset appreciation started to form. The venture capital industry formalized its lobbying efforts by founding the NVCA, for which Reid Dennis and Pitch Johnson both acted as presidents (Dennis, 2009, p. 33). Dennis pinpoints Carter's proposal as the turning point for venture capitalists:  

[I]t got them galvanized into action in a way that nobody else had ever been galvanized before, to get together and do something about this thing. If it hadn't been for Carter's statement that we should get rid of all of the distinction between ordinary income and capital gains, I think we would have drifted along, and they would have nickeled and dimed us to death by making small changes all along the line until the industry was wiped out. (Dennis,2009, p. 33)  

The concerted lobbying pushback proved so effective that it overshot its initial goal of halting an increase in capital gains taxation. With the Revenue Act of 1978, Carter proposed a highly diluted reform bill. Derided by critics as a ‘millionaires' relief bill, it lowered the long-term capital gains tax rate to $25\%$ .TheWashington Post captured the general spirit of this change by observing that ‘the Ways and Means Committee last week gleefully refused even to disallow business deductions for more than 22 martinis (for one person) a day or yachts exceeding 35 feet in length' (Lardner, 1978). With the passing of the Revenue Act, investors and employees holding stocks in quickly growing companies would only be taxed $25\%$ and therefore at a considerably lower rate than income tax.  

According to Reid Dennis (2009), referring to the first and second capital gains tax reduction which followed in 1981, the lowering of the capital gains tax made starting companies much more lucrative: managers just came pouring out of big companies to start their own—there were more startups started in 1980 than I think almost any year in the history of the business until recently' (p. 35). The pull of lower taxation coincided with a push of institutional capital. In 1979, the US Department of Labor clarified and effectively eased the ERISA fiduciary responsibility guidelines. This decisively changed VC's capital supply and is often referred to as the opening of the floodgates for venture capital funding.  

### 1980s and beyond: a small solution to abundance at large  

The previous sections traced the formalization and scaling of VC's financial infrastructure in tandem with a tightening alliance of asset owners. The limited partnership emerged as the most suitable organizational form for absorbing large amounts of capital. As this form was replicated and deployed at scale, the limited partnership hardened into a financial infrastructure for VC investing that remained central for the coming decades. Soener and Nau (2019, p. 407) revealed that between 1980 and 2010, the number of limited partnerships in the US more than doubled. Although a majority of these were not set up for the purposes of VC investing, this clearly underlines the durability (Abourahme & Jabary-Salamanca, 2016; Bernards & Campbell-Verduyn, 2019) and broader impact of limited partnerships as financial infrastructure. Limited partnerships were able to handle the influx of large amounts of capital and at the same time offered the legal conditions for the actors engaged with them to maximize their capital gains.  

The ERISA clarification opened new sources of funds for venture capitalists. The surging inflow of money put the limited partnership's capacity to absorb capital to the test. Gompers (1994) observes that the ‘change explicitly allowed fund managers to invest up to $10\%$ of their capital in venture funds. Pension fund commitments to venture capital rose dramatically, increasing annual new contributions to venture capital funds from $\$100$ to 200 [million] during the 1970s to in excess of $\$4$ billion by the end of the $1980s^{\prime}$ (p. 12). Further, Gompers et al. (1998, p. 165) show a drastic increase in net new commitments to independent venture capital partnerships, rising from US $\$480$ million to US $\$5.30$ billion in 1987.2 This is an astounding development. To put this into perspective, only a decade earlier Kleiner Perkins raised a US $\$8$ million fund in 1972, the largest ever at this point in time, and failed to invest half of it.3  

On the back of this new financial infrastructure, fundamental change in the US economy ensued. As Gompers (1994) points out, “[p]rior to 1980, firms created the majority of new jobs in the American economy. During the last decade [the 1980s], however, a major structural shift occurred. Fortune 500 companies lost 4 million jobs. At the same time, firms with fewer than 100 employees added 16 million new jobs [...] This was the first time in the twentieth century that the shift from large to small firms occurred and it represented a fundamental change in the nature of growth in the American economy’ (p. 1, emphasis added). This observation ties in withRothstein's(2022) argument that VCscredibly soldadigital transformation-centered growth model. My point here is not that VCs funded all these small firms. Rather, there was a financial infrastructure in place to amplify this trend further and funnel money toward a rising number of newly incorporated companies who could trial new (feeble) business ideas for longer or even the first time at all.  

The structural change that VCs affected was that they now funded and sustained companies and business models that under different circumstances, in the absence of such a financial infrastructure, would have had no viability. This handling of abundance changed firm creation and the economics of entire sectors. As Reid Dennis (2009) observes, ‘in the huge bull market of venture capital and fundraising, pension funds have become a major source of capital, and it's one of the things that has flooded the industry with so much capital that it doesn't know what to do with it (p. 30, emphasis added). In the 1980s, Gompers (1994) describes how this situation, what I would term a ‘problem of abundance, informed the investment craze for hard disk companies: ‘the sudden and dramatic increase in venture capital commitments meant they had to find something in which to invest. The large fraction of inexperienced venture capitalists changed the rules of investing’ (p. 18). This ‘bull market could be read as the pro-cyclicality story of VC, investments rising with buoyant stock markets. However, this reading neglects the push from concentrated capital. The term ^solution, hence, must be taken with a grain of salt. As capitalist development often rests on contradictions, the erstwhile solution to the problem of abundance for VCs created new problems almost instantaneously.  

### Abundance and asset-driven inequalities  

A central claim of this paper is that VCs made important innovations that at the time solved their personal problems of abundance. By enrolling employees and institutional investors into their alliance of asset owners, these solutions changed how problems of abundance were solved not only on the personal but also the macro scale. The 2000s and 2010s were characterized by this type of abundance of capital. Particularly in reaction to the 2008 global financial crisis, major central banks pursued expansive monetary policy aiming to inject vast amounts of liquidity into the financial system. This policy coupled quantitative easing with ultra-low interest rates, ensuring cheap credit and driving down yields on bonds while raising yields on equities. Now institutional investors, unable to make returns on low yielding bonds, found themselves in a situation where they had capital that they didn't know what to do with.  

Policy makers? initial intention to spur liberal lending, and with that investment, growth, and employment, produced contentious outcomes. A central point of critique is that quantitative easing inflated the value of assets like equities and real estate while growth and employment remained anemic (Blyth, 2015). Recent scholarship has analyzed the effects of asset ownership, control, and appreciation for societal inequality (Adkins et al., 2020; Braun, 2016, 2021; Christophers, 2023). The macroeconomic regime is commonly understood to have empowered the owners of assets. The alliance of asset owners, and VCs chiefly among them, interacted with this condition of abundance in four key ways.  

First, VCs did not bring this macroeconomic environment into being, but they pioneered a solution for handling abundant cash (and making it appreciate through tech asset investments) that was now used by investors on a much larger scale. VCs set up a financial infrastructure that funneled money into quickly appreciating tech assets. In 2008, US venture capitalists invested US $\$29$ billion annually. By 2022, this number had increased more than 6-fold to US $\$190$ billion (OECD, 2022). At this volume, especially given that this money is distributed to young companies, considerable parts of the contemporary economy depend on these abundant funds. This is either because of a highly risky business model that can only be financed by VCs or because businesses depend on investors’ money as life support until they reach profitability (Kenney & Zysman,2019).  

Second, channeling abundance this way creates a very particular financialization of the firm, of business models which can run on operations that would not work under normal conditions of capitalism. Many of these companies are not primarily profit-driven but growth-driven, as profits can remain elusive for a while on the back of the funding deluge. I discussed Schwartz's claim earlier that inter-firm inequality is worsened through IPR regimes and that individual level inequality is worsened by shifting labor and physical assets outside the legal boundary of the firm. Abundance furthers both: VCs decide which companies get a lifeline of funding to ‘disrupt their industries of choice until the economics eventually work out, clearly worsening inter-firm inequality. Beyond that, VCs also format the functioning of the firms they fund with the financial imperatives they impose (Shestakofsky, 2024). This influences individual level inequality through the terms of employment that firms offer, with gig workers as a stark example.  

Third, VCs made a crucial contribution to elevating institutional investors (now looking to deploy their cash) to their structural importance in our current stage of capitalism. As demonstrated earlier, enrolling institutional investors into the alliance of asset owners opened up equity investments for the first time besides the then dominant investments in bonds. They made actors realize that they have a shared goal in asset appreciation and should orient their actions (e.g. lobbying) toward it with combined clout. Today, VCs are gatekeepers’ (Cooiman, 2024) of tech startup investments, and institutional investors are their suppliers of capital. Between 2012 and 2016, US venture capitalists distributed a total sum of US $\$260$ billion (OECD, 2022). During this time span, private and public pensions funds constituted $38\%$ of venture capital funds’ limited partner base, followed by foundations $(29.8\%)$ and endowments $(21.2\%)$ (Lenhard et al., 2023, p. 8). VC's disproportionate influence on shaping the economy hinges on institutional investors strong interest in allocating money into highly risky equity investments.  

Lastly, VCs constructed a financial infrastructure for their personal enrichment, which was supercharged by the generalized condition of abundance. As explained above, in VC limited partnerships the annual $2{-}3\%$ management fee of total fund volume flows toward the VC firm irrespective of performance. In times when leading VC firms raise fund volumes in the billions of US dollars, this is a considerable sum. Growing the total paid-in capital hence raises the revenue of the VC firm. Braun (2022, p. 643) contends that asset managers drive a similar strategy of maximizing their fee revenue by growing their assets under management. In this case, even before asset appreciation, increased volume simply drives the opportunity for personal enrichment based on salaries.  

However, this does not eclipse asset appreciation as the major driver of the inequal distribution of gains. Highlighting the role of VCs in making asset appreciation pay off for these groups of people reveals the political stakes: A small elite group of investors had a disproportionate influence on who gets to benefit from capital abundance. They pioneered a particular handling of abundance that furthered the reproduction of inequalities. This makes the asset economy a playing field for the extraordinarily wealthy.  

### The solution to abundance and its problems  

The history presented above tied wealth inequality much more explicitly into the history of VC. I showed the lineage from wealthy elites with abundant funds at their disposal to modern day VC firms and their limited partnerships. With the example of Fairchild and stock options, limited partnerships winning over Small Business Investment Corporations, and the lobbying for the ERISA easing and lowering of capital gains tax, I highlighted the centrality of VCs in engineering asset appreciation. Elites are not only concerned with the reproduction of their own wealth but (at times inadvertently) reformat how entire sectors of the economy work. I used the concept of financial infrastructure to examine the legal constructs in the form of limited partnerships that enabled and scaled this financial restructuring. VCs enrolled other actors, limited partners, and employees, into an alliance of asset owners now bound together through this financial infrastructure. I showed the VC-fueled and institutional investor-funded disruption of existing industries and the rise of the gig economy as effects of this. They furthered the financialization of firms, allocating capital to far from ideal uses and obtaining a share of the gains incommensurate with the risk or labor invested. In sum, VCs deepened asset-driven inequalities by devising a particular handling of abundance, which materialized in building a financial infrastructure for their needs.  

The broader concern of this paper was VCs relationship with financialization and how a focus on abundance can clarify this relationship. It was the ambition of this paper to highlight the importance of this group of actors next to explanations of financialized capitalism that have focused on policy makers (Krippner, 2012), and structural transformations of capitalism (Brenner, 2006; Schwartz, 2016b). What would financialized tech capitalism look like today without VC? In addition to the established importance of VCs in lowering capital gains taxation, easing ERISA, and establishing stock options, this paper showed that more broadly, it is difficult to imagine that some of the reinforcing dynamics of the alliance of asset owners would have been possible without VC as a binding and driving force. Institutional investors looking for outlets for their capital in a low interest environment would not have been able to put that money into VC and by extension the digital economy. The fact that it is virtually impossible to scale a tech company without venture capital financing today, due to competitive pressures and the need for capital-intensive product and service development and expansion, suggests that the digital economy would have taken a fundamentally different shape.  

While the 2010s were an era of abundant capital, the following decade saw a rise in interest rates that ended the free money’ bonanza for many investors. While funding levels have dropped, the financial infrastructure remains in place and has proven sturdy for financing the generative AI hype. More critically, the onset of a new macroeconomic regime invites us to take a closer look at how different types of asset owners work to maintain their access to the financial infrastructure built by VCs-and whether they can keep benefitting from it.
